occurrences.line_text: Till he his armes about her sides gan fold,
Till through wise handling and faire gouernance,
Till comming to this well, he stoupt to drincke:
Till guiltie bloud her guerdon doe obtaine:
And throwen forth, till it be withered:
Till that at last they to a Castle came,
Till it the pitch of highest prayse exceeds:
Till I that false Acrasia haue wonne;
Till that at length with Archimage they meet:
And now hath vowd, till he auenged bee,
Till that they come vnto a forrest greene,
Till she to him her gratious speach renewed;
And therfore wisht me stay, till I more truth should fynd.
Till that the truth thereof I did outwrest,
Till this mad man, whom your victorious might
Till at the last all breathlesse, wearie, faint
Such homage till that instant neuer learned hee.
Till that the Palmer, by his graue restraint,
Till they arriued in that pleasant Ile,
Till season serue new passage to assay;
And euer bad him stay, till time the tide renewd.
Thing offred, till I know it well be got,
Till that they came vnto an yron dore,
To wonder at the sight: for till that day,
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
Till Mammon did his hasty hand withhold,
She by creation was, till she did fall;
Till partiall Paris dempt it Venus dew,
Till him the child bespoke, Long lackt, alas,
Till that they spide, where towards them did pace
Till vengeance vtterly the guilt bereaue:
Till that at last, when he aduantage spyde,
Till him the Prince with gentle court did bord;
Till that the Squire gan nigher to approch;
Till the fierce Northerne wind with blustring blast
Till by a conduit pipe it thence were brought:
Till Alma him bespake, Why wonder yee
Till that great Ladie thence away them sought,
Till it reduced was to one mans gouernments.
till time of Gloriane.
Till that the venturous Mariner that way
And threw in bands, where he till death remaind;
Till ryper yeares he raught, and stronger stay:
Till that her sisters children, woxen strong
Till wearie of that wretched life, her selfe she hong.
And Gorbogud, till farre in yeares he grew:
For till his dayes, the chiefe dominion
Till by his death he it recouered;
Till they outraigned had their vtmost date,
Till he surrendred Realme and life to fate.
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
Till the prowd Romanes him disquieted,
Till Arthur all that reckoning did defray;
Forwasted all, till Genuissa gent
Till murdred by the friends of Gratian;
Till by consent of Commons and of Peares,
Till that through poyson stopped was his breath;
Till gentle Alma seeing it so late,
Till that the Prince seeing her wofull plight,
Till that the villein comming to their ayd,
Till it dissolued be from earthly band.
At need, till now, he lightly threw away,
Ne stird, till hope of life did him forsake;
Till that Latona traueiling that way,
Till that the Palmer gan full bitterly
They were faire Ladies, till they fondly striu'd
Till that at last the weather gan to cleare,
Till that he came vnto another gate,
Till they arriued, where they lately had
Till that she rushing through the thickest preasse,
Ne did she stay, till three on ground she layd,
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
The mortall steele stayd not, till it was seene
Till enuious Men fearing their rules decay,
Till death make one end of my dayes and miserie.
Till thou in open field adowne be smot.
Till that by dew degrees and long pretence,
Them bound till his returne, their labour not to slake.
Till they to heauens hight forth stretched bee.
Till vniuersall peace compound all ciuill iarre.
Till thy wombes burden thee from them do call,
Till both the sonnes of Edwin he haue slaine,
Consume, till all their warlike puissaunce be spent.
Ne rested they, till that to Faery lond
Till that to the sea-coast at length she her addrest.
Till that old Glauce gan with sharpe repriefe,
The world in darkenesse dwels, till that at last
Till sadly soucing on the sandie shore,
Long time she fostred vp, till he became
To finde some issue thence, till that at last
Till him aliue or dead she did inuent.
For till thou tidings learne, what her betide,
Ne ceased not, till him oppressed hard
Till he had made amends, and full restore
The wicked steele stayd not, till it did light
Till that through weaknesse he was forst at last,
Till to her dew perfection she was ripened.
Till faint through irkesome wearinesse, adowne
Which still increast, till she her terme had full outgone.
Till that vnweeldy burden she had reard,
So long they sought, till they arriued were
Till they againe returne backe by the hinder gate.
Till thither they returne, where first they grew:
So long she trauelled, till at length she came
Till her he had attaind, and brought in place,
Yet neuer learned he such seruice, till that day.
Till I so many other Dames had found,
Till on a day, as he disposed was
Till triall doe more certaine truth bewray.
Your zealous hast, till morrow next againe
Thereat displeasd they were, till that young Squire
Till that young Squire him reared from below;
Ne would they eate, till she in presence came.
Till he with old Latinus was constraind,
Till Romulus renewing it, to Rome remoud.
That ryde he could not, till his hurts he did amend.
His secret drift, till he her layd abord.
Gaue them safe conduct, till to end they came:
Till that prickt forth with loues extremitie,
Till Trompart ronning hastily, him did stay,
Till Trompart lowly to the ground inclind,
Till on a day the Satyres her espide
Till we returne againe in safetie:
Till drouping Phoebus gan to hide his golden hed.
He wooed her, till day spring he espyde;
Ne stayes, till safe himselfe he see from ieopardy.
Ne stayd he, till he came vnto the place,
Till that he came vnto a rockie hill,
Till so she do, she must in doole remaine,
Till they arriu'd, whereas their purpose they did plot.
Till morrow next, she did her selfe auize,
Till that againe the second euening
At this same furrowes end, till a new day:
Lo thus they rode, till at the last they spide
Till on his way they had him forth conuayd:
Till that ere long they chaunced to espie
Till that the rest him seeing lie on ground,
Till time the tryall of her truth expyred:
Till seeing her, that Florimell did seme,
To stay their hands, till he a while had spoken:
Till that to ripenesse of mans state they grew:
That nought mote stay the steele, till in his side
Till Diamond disdeigning long delay
Till feeling life to fayle, it fell, and deadly slept.
Till th'heat of his fierce furie he had spent:
Till hauing often by him stricken beene,
And with her alwaies ride, till he another get.
Till then your challenges ye may prolong;
Till that at length vpon th'appointed day,
Staid not, till it arriued in his side.
Till that he came, where he had Cambell seene,
Till trumpets sound did warne them all to rest;
Till that there entred on the other side,
Till euening, that the Sunne gan downward bend.
So nought may be esteemed happie till the end.
Till by mishap he in his foemens hand did light.
Till Blandamour, who thought he had the trew
Till that at last the gentle Amoret
Till on her horses hinder parts it fell;
Till on a day as through a desert wyld
Till Glauce thus; Faire Sir, be nought dismayd
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
Till Britomart him fairely thus behight;
Till I her find, and wreake on him that her did reaue.
Till they with mariage meet might finish that accord.
But till the horned moone three courses did expire.
Ran, till he came to th'end of all his way,
Till thou cam'st hither to augment our mone,
That ioyd in happy peace, till fates peruerse
Till I thereto had all things ready dight.
Where yet vntouched till this present day,
Till time for him should remedy prouide,
Till time the tempest doe thereof delay
Till on a day, as in his wonted wise
Till she drew neare, and then againe remoue;
Till that at length into that forrest wide,
Till on a day as through that wood he rode,
And rayl'd and rag'd, till she had all her poyson spent.
Till she had duld the sting, which in her tongs end grew.
My selfe, till that the Dwarfe did me reueale,
Till fortune did perforce it so decree.
Till to his castle they approched neare.
Till better him bethinking of the right,
Till he had made of her some better priefe,
Whose like they neuer saw till that same houre:
Till that vneath they forced were for lacke
Till Scudamour, and that same Briton maide,
First from one coast, till nought thereof be drie;
And then another, till that likewise fleet;
And so from side to side till all the world it weet.
Till seeing them through suffrance hartned more,
Till to the Bridges vtter gate I came:
Till at the last I spide within the same,
Till I was throughly past the perill of his reach.
Till now at last relenting, she to him was wed.
His way still vnder ground, till Thamis he ouertake.
Till like a victor on his backe he ride,
That made him stoupe, till he did him bestride:
Till they arriue at their last ruinous decay.
For till the world from his perfection fell
In which she noursled him, till yeares he raught,
Till he of tidings mote with him discourse.
Till that at length nigh to the sea they drew;
Till we may be assur'd they shall their course retaine.
Till Florimell about her fastned it.
Hence fare on foot, till he an horse haue gayned.
Till he had questioned the cause of their dissent.
I will not rest, till I her might doe trie,
Till they had told their message word by word:
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
Till he to her deliuered had his shield,
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
Till I the conquest of my will recouer.
Ne would she stay, till he in place could come,
Till she againe thus sayd; Talus be bold,
Ne would abide, till she had aunswere made,
Thus passing th'euening well, till time of rest,
Those warlike weedes, till she reuenge had wrought
Till to the perillous Bridge she came, and there
Till to the Bridges further end she past,
Ne rested till she cam without relent
Stayd not, till she came to her selfe againe,
Till through his want her woe did more increase:
Till he redeemed had that Lady thrall:
Till that at length she did before her spie
Till he himselfe was made their greedie pray,
Stayd not, till through his curat it did glyde,
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
So forth they past, till they approched ny
But he the bush did beat, till that at last
Till strong constraint did her thereto enforce.
Which till this day mongst many liuing are,
It was not long, till that the Prince arriued
Till that th'offended heauens list to lowre
Ne stayed step, till that he came at last
Till ye haue rooted all the relickes out
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
For if I liue till those ten daies haue end,
Till that a Tyrant, which Grandtorto hight,
Ne ceassed not, till all their scattred crew
Till Artegall him seeing so to rage,
Till he an Herauld cald, and to him spake,
There wayting for the Tyrant, till it was farre day.
Till it to ripenesse grew, and forth to honour burst.
Till I him ouertake, or else subdew:
Till he to perfect ripenesse grew, and then
Till his returne vnto this tree he bond:
Till of his wounds he wexed hole and strong,
Or stay till he his armes, which were thereby,
So passed we, till this young man vs met,
In Cornewale, till that he through liues despeire
Whom on his backe he bore, till he him brought
So they the euening past, till time of rest,
To leaue, till to her fathers house he had her brought.
Till to that Ladies fathers house he came;
Till to some place of rest they mote attaine,
Till she recured were of those her woundes wide.
So fare on foote till thou another gayne,
Yet if he needes will fight, craue leaue till morne,
Till that at length, in his extreamest neede,
Wherefore he stayd, till that he nearer drew,
Not satisfyde till on the fatall ground
Till that by fortune, passing all foresight,
The saluage man, that neuer till this houre
Till that his Ladies sight he mote attaine,
till she Prince Arthure fynd,
Till that at length vnto a woody glade
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
Till towards night they came vnto a plaine,
Till that the morning, bringing earely light
It neuer rests, till it haue wrought his finall bane.
So both together traueld, till they met
Till that, as comes by course, I doe recite,
Ne stayd, till that he came into the hall:
Till that he him deliuered to his punishment.
Till she had sau'd so many loues, as she did lose.
Till heauy hand the Carle vpon him layd,
Till Mirabellaes fortunes I doe further say.
Till they him force the buxome yoke to beare:
Till the sharpe passion being ouerpast,
Till I haue sau'd so many, as I earst did slay.
Till to the brim I haue it full defrayd:
Long thus she fled, till that at last she thought
Till being waked with these loud alarmes,
And rest himselfe, till supper time befell.
From chacing him, till he had it attchieued?
Till fortune fraught with malice, blinde, and brute,
Till Fortune would her captiue bonds vnbynde:
Till some, which did the sundry prisoners knowe,
So there all day they bode, till light the sky forsooke.
So long till all the entry was with bodies mand.
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
Till he had strowd with bodies all the way;
And Bellamour in bands, till that her syre
Till time that Calidore brought Pastorella thether.
Is forcibly kept downe, till he be throughly queld.
Straunge bands, whose like till then he neuer bore,
Ne euer any durst till then impose,
And falsed oft his blowes, t'illude him with such bayt.
And goodly taught to tilt and turnament;
At tilt or tourney, or like warlike game,
Turne we our steedes, that both in equall tilt
And better skild in Tilt and Turnament,
Sir Artegall into the Tilt-yard came,
His timbered bones all broken rudely rumbled:
As when the Mast of some well timbred hulke
And in their hands sweet Timbrels all vpheld on hight.
As time her taught, in lowly Shepheards weeds,
Yet armes till that time did he neuer wield:
With loue, long time did languish as the striken hind.
Long time they thus together traueiled,
And in the witch vnweeting ioyd long time,
But how long time, said then the Elfin knight,
Time and suffised fates to former kynd
And long time hauing tand his tawney hide
But Ladies loue as losse of time forbore:
And them long time before, great Nimrod was,
And yieldes her to extremitie of time;
And long time with that saluage people staid,
During which time her gentle wit she plyes,
That she conceiu'd; and trebling the dew time,
He chose, which he had kept long time in darksome den.
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
As losse of time, and vertues enimy
As when iust time expired should appeare.
During which time, in euery good behest
High time now gan it wex for Vna faire,
The Nourse of time, and euerlasting fame,
Of auncient time there was a springing well,
Which long time had bene shut, and out of hond
He was affiaunced long time before,
That still he sate long time astonished
And fained cheare, as for the time behoues,
In which we long time without gealous feares,
By this time was the worthy Guyon brought
And euer bad him stay, till time the tide renewd.
Whom he had long time sought with fruitlesse suit:
For lenger time, then that, no liuing wight
Pyrrochles gan reply the second time,
Then like a Lion, which hath long time saught
But Ã´; great pitty, that no lenger time
When cause requird, but neuer out of time;
So that no time, nor reason could arize,
till time of Gloriane.
Polluted this same gentle soyle long time:
During which time her powre she did display
Who peaceably the same long time did weld:
In whose sad time bloud did from heauen raine:
And goodly well long time it gouerned,
What time th'eternall Lord in fleshly slime
O ioyous memorie of happy time,
Who after long debate, since Lucies time,
Long time in peace his Realme established,
That how the time was fled, they quite forgate,
Amid th'AegÃ¦an sea long time did stray,
His fearefull face in time of greatest storme,
Gather the Rose of love, whilest yet is time,
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
High time it seemed then for euery wight
What time king Ryence raign'd, and dealed right,
The time, that mortall men their weary cares
In the meane time through that false Ladies traine,
Long time ye both in armes shall beare great sway,
Hath long time slept, himselfe so shall he shake,
But the third time shall faire accordaunce make:
Yet shall he long time warre with happy speed,
But the third time shall rew his foolhardise:
When the full time prefixt by destiny,
That of the time doth dew aduauntage take;
It fortuned (so time their turne did fit)
Long time she fostred vp, till he became
His mother swowned thrise, and the third time
Who long time wandred through the forrest wyde,
Thus warreid he long time against his will,
So was she trayned vp from time to time,
So was she trayned vp from time to time,
Is wicked Time, who with his scyth addrest,
All things decay in time, and to their end do draw.
But were it not, that Time their troubler is,
Continuall, both meeting at one time:
During which time, the Chorle through her so kind
Either for want of handsome time and place,
His foolish maladie, and long time had misled.
Her to disport, and idle time to pas,
The which to let you weet, will further time require.
That in a cloud their light did long time stay,
Where faire it florished, and long time it stoud,
Where wearie wandring they long time did wonne,
The learned louer lost no time nor tyde,
Nought wants but time and place, which shortly shee
Was neuer better time to shew thy smart,
Lewd Losse of Time, and Sorrow seeming dead,
For from the time that Scudamour her bought
Vntill such time as noble Britomart
What time the dayes with scorching heat abound,
Till time the tryall of her truth expyred:
Such Musicke is wise words with time concented,
What time his people into partes did riue,
That on a time as they together way'd,
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
But euermore, when she fit time could fynd,
What time she vsd to liue in wiuely sort;
Fit time t'awaite auenged for to bee.
Well weened all, which her that time did vew,
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
For time yet serues that I the same refuse,
The which long time his grieued hart did wound,
For from that time I from enchaunters theft
In all which time, Sir Artegall made way
Tho when they had long time there taken rest,
Fit time for him thence to depart it found,
Of this or that, the time for to delay,
Time to my will, and from his wrathfull sight
Hast thou in all this time, from him vnknowne
That in short time his face they ouergrew,
Till time for him should remedy prouide,
Till time the tempest doe thereof delay
In which he long time afterwards did lead
Of time, did liue then like an innocent,
So twixt themselues they pointed time and place,
Who now long time had lyen in prison sad,
What time the fame of this renowmed prise
And time to steale, the threasure of mans day;
In which he long time after did remaine
Whereof conceiuing, she in time forth brought
It was no time to scan the prophecie,
So oft as I with state of present time,
As all things else in time are chaunged quight.
That makes me feare in time he will vs quite forsake.
That since the time they first tooke the Sunnes hight,
The fortune of her life long time did feare.
Should be solemniz'd: for if time he had,
What time if naught me let, I will be there
That she might win some time, though dearly bought
The time and place was blazed farre and wide;
Vnlesse some succour had in time him ouertaken.
And taking vsurie of time forepast,
That when as time to Artegall shall tend,
But tract of time, that all things doth decay,
Before which time I lou'd, as was my lot,
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
During which time, the warlike Amazon,
Now is the time, that I vntimely must
From time to time, when thou it best shalt see,
From time to time, when thou it best shalt see,
Yet to awayt fit time she weened best,
And with faire words, fit for the time and place,
What time sad tydings of his balefull smart
She fayn'd to count the time againe anew,
Thus passing th'euening well, till time of rest,
What time the natiue Belman of the night,
And tempred for the time her present heauinesse.
As the bright sunne, what time his fierie teme
That well could charme his tongue, and time his speach
Stryuing long time in vaine it to withstond;
That right long time is ouerborne of wrong,
One time, when he his weapon faynd to shift,
And the third time out of an hidden shade,
Not so; (quoth he) for yet when time doth serue,
Had it forslackt. But now time drawing ny,
And time and place conuenient to areed,
Which with strong powre did them long time oppresse;
During which time, that he did there remaine,
She long time hath deare lou'd a doughty Knight,
Ne time would giue, nor any termes aby,
And being now high time these strong ioynts to imploy.
Yet for the time this answere he to him behight.
So they the euening past, till time of rest,
During which time, that wyld man did apply
For hauing long time, as his daily weed,
And like in time to further ill to grow,
All is in time like to returne againe
As ye may know, when time shall be to tell the same.
Who when as now long time he lacked had
Vpon a day as they the time did waite,
As to them seemed fit time to entertaine.
Vntill fit time and place he mote espy,
For to auenge, in time conuenient,
Whylest time did offer meanes him sleeping to surprize.
To seeke for safety, which long time she sought:
In winters wrathfull time, he forced him to flie.
That she in tract of time accompted was his owne.
And rest himselfe, till supper time befell.
The time was once, in my first prime of yeares,
During which time he did her entertaine
What time the golden apple was vnto him brought.
Long time had lou'd, and hop'd her loue to gaine,
Another time, when as they did dispose
The fruite of ioy and blisse, though long time dearely bought.
Thus Calidore continu'd there long time,
Long time, as fit occasion forth them led;
That he in time her ioyaunce should obtaine.
But gently waking them, gaue them the time of day.
And in dew time a mayden child forth brought.
Till time that Calidore brought Pastorella thether.
Albe that long time after Calidore,
But rends without regard of person or of time.
With timely pride aboue the Aegyptian vale,
Then with the Sunne take Sir, your timely rest,
And on the top a Diall told the timely howres.
